title: Abstract for Unit 4 Lesson 4
body: This lesson focuses on evaluating and implementing a Participatory Sensing campaign. Students will finalize the design of their community-focused campaign, brainstorm data collection methods, and create survey questions. They will then evaluate the feasibility and ethical soundness of their campaign design. The lesson includes rounds for refining research questions, identifying data types and triggers, developing survey prompts, and assessing question clarity and bias. Students will also generate statistical questions to guide their campaign and consider the practicality and privacy implications of their data collection. The lesson concludes with a discussion on the campaign's reasonableness and ethical considerations, followed by a homework assignment to mock implement the campaign and collect data.

title: Objective for Unit 4 Lesson 4
body: The primary objective of Unit 4 Lesson 4 is for students to complete the design of their community-focused Participatory Sensing campaign. Following this, they will implement a mock version of their campaign to evaluate its overall feasibility. This hands-on approach ensures students understand the practical aspects of campaign design and implementation before real-world application.

title: Materials for Unit 4 Lesson 4
body: The essential material for Unit 4 Lesson 4 is the 'Team Campaign Creation' handout. This handout, referenced as LMR_U4_L2, was introduced in a previous lesson (Unit 4 Lesson 2). Students will utilize this document to record and refine the details of their Participatory Sensing campaign design throughout this lesson.

title: Essential Concepts for Unit 4 Lesson 4
body: Unit 4 Lesson 4 emphasizes two key concepts. Firstly, statistical questions are crucial for guiding a Participatory Sensing campaign, enabling the collection of meaningful data about a community or individuals. Secondly, it is vital to evaluate these campaigns thoroughly before implementation to ensure they are both reasonable in their scope and ethically sound in their approach to data collection and privacy.

title: Lesson Procedure: Round 3 - Data and Triggers (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: In Unit 4 Lesson 4, student teams continue designing their Participatory Sensing campaigns. During Round 3, teams engage in a brainstorm to identify the specific types of data required to answer their chosen research question. They also determine the most effective time or event ('trigger') to initiate data collection or survey completion. A key consideration during this phase is to ensure the selected data directly addresses the research question.

title: Lesson Procedure: Survey Question Creation (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Following the identification of data types and triggers in Unit 4 Lesson 4, teams move on to create survey questions or prompts. These questions are designed to collect the necessary data when the predetermined trigger event occurs. The focus is on crafting clear and effective prompts that solicit the required information relevant to the campaign's research question.

title: Lesson Procedure: Round 4 - Evaluating Survey Questions (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Unit 4 Lesson 4 includes Round 4, where teams evaluate the survey questions and prompts they have created. For each question, students consider its type (e.g., number, text, photo), its contribution to answering the research question, and whether it needs rewording for clarity. A strategy suggested is for teams to pair up and ask each other prompts to assess understanding and identify areas for improvement. Rewritten questions are then finalized as a team.

title: Lesson Procedure: Recording Campaign Details (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: After finalizing their survey questions and prompts in Unit 4 Lesson 4, students record this information on their 'Team Campaign Creation' handout (LMR_U4_L2). This step involves noting the survey question/prompt associated with each data variable. Teams are reminded to be mindful of potential question bias during this recording process, ensuring the questions elicit neutral and accurate responses.

title: Lesson Procedure: Round 5 - Statistical Questions and Evaluation (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Unit 4 Lesson 4 progresses to Round 5, where teams generate up to three statistical questions that their campaign data can help answer. These questions should be interesting and relevant to the campaign's topic, also accounting for the collected data on date, time, and place. The lesson emphasizes confirming that these questions are indeed statistical and answerable with the proposed data. Teachers circulate to verify this. Finally, teams evaluate the overall reasonableness and ethical soundness of their campaign, considering data variability, campaign manageability, trigger frequency, privacy concerns, and sufficiency of data for answering statistical questions. Adjustments are made if necessary.

title: Evaluating Campaign Reasonableness and Ethics (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: A critical part of Unit 4 Lesson 4 involves evaluating the reasonableness and ethical implications of the designed Participatory Sensing campaign. Teams discuss whether survey answers are likely to vary, if the campaign is executable, and if trigger frequency is optimal (not too rare, not too frequent). Crucially, they consider privacy and potential embarrassment from sharing data. They assess if changes to triggers or questions can improve the campaign and if enough relevant data can be gathered to answer their statistical questions. This evaluation ensures the campaign is practical and respects ethical considerations.

title: Finalizing the Campaign Design (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: By the end of Unit 4 Lesson 4, student teams have collaboratively created their complete Team Participatory Sensing campaign. This includes defining their research question, identifying necessary data types and triggers, crafting and refining survey questions, developing guiding statistical questions, and evaluating the campaign for reasonableness and ethical soundness. Any necessary adjustments based on this evaluation are made, resulting in a finalized campaign plan.

title: Class Scribes Activity (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: In Unit 4 Lesson 4, a 'Class Scribes' activity is included. One team of students is responsible for presenting a brief talk to the class. Their presentation should summarize what they consider to be the three most important topics or takeaways from the day's lesson. This activity encourages synthesis and communication of key learning points.

title: Homework Assignment for Unit 4 Lesson 4
body: The homework assignment for Unit 4 Lesson 4 requires students to engage in a mock implementation of their developed Team Participatory Sensing campaign. The purpose of this assignment is for students to actively collect data according to their campaign design. This practical exercise will provide valuable insights into the real-world application and potential challenges of their campaign before any larger-scale implementation.

title: Participatory Sensing Campaigns and Statistical Questions (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Unit 4 Lesson 4 highlights the fundamental role of statistical questions in guiding Participatory Sensing campaigns. These questions direct the data collection process, enabling students to learn about their community or themselves. The lesson emphasizes that campaigns should be designed with specific statistical questions in mind and thoroughly evaluated for feasibility and ethical soundness before implementation. This ensures the collected data will be meaningful and the campaign conducted responsibly.

title: Data Collection Triggers and Survey Design (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Within Unit 4 Lesson 4, a significant focus is placed on determining data collection triggers and designing effective survey questions. Students brainstorm the types of data needed to answer their research question and identify the best triggers (events or times) for data collection. Subsequently, they create survey prompts that elicit this specific data when the trigger occurs. The process includes evaluating these prompts for clarity and relevance, ensuring they directly contribute to answering the campaign's statistical questions.

title: Evaluating Survey Question Quality (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: Unit 4 Lesson 4 involves a detailed evaluation of survey questions within student teams. For each question, students assess its type (e.g., numerical, textual, photographic), its relevance to the research question, and its clarity. Rewording is encouraged if a question is ambiguous or difficult to answer. Peer feedback by having teams exchange and attempt to answer each other's prompts is a key strategy employed to improve question quality and ensure the collected data is accurate and useful for the campaign's objectives.

title: Campaign Feasibility and Ethical Considerations (Unit 4 Lesson 4)
body: A crucial aspect of Unit 4 Lesson 4 is the evaluation of a Participatory Sensing campaign's feasibility and ethical implications. Teams discuss if data answers will vary, if the campaign is practical to carry out, and if the frequency of triggers is manageable. Ethical considerations, such as privacy and the potential for embarrassment from data sharing, are paramount. Teams assess if adjustments to triggers or questions are needed and if sufficient relevant data can be gathered to address their statistical questions, ensuring the campaign is both viable and responsible.
